key_points: Vice President Kamala Harris announces a nationwide Call to Action to improve maternal health and reduce mortality and morbidity.
The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) estimates 720,000 more people could gain Medicaid postpartum coverage if all states extend coverage.
The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) propose a new "Birthing-Friendly" hospital designation and issue guidance for year-long Medicaid postpartum coverage.
The Biden-Harris Administration emphasizes addressing maternal health as a key priority, highlighting the significant disparity among Black women and Native American women.
The Administration marks the first-ever White House Maternal Health Day of Action and announces new commitments under the Build Back Better Act.

The Build Back Better Act proposes a $3 billion investment in maternal health, including improvements in workforce diversity, data collection, social factors, substance use disorders, research, coverage, and care coordination.
States are encouraged to expand Medicaid coverage to 12 months postpartum, a significant increase from the current 60 days.
A new HHS report shows the benefits of extending Medicaid postpartum coverage to a full year.
The United States has the highest maternal mortality rate among wealthy nations, worsening over the past 20 years, particularly for Black and Native American women.
Vice President Harris has historically advocated for improved maternal health through legislation like the Maternal CARE Act and the Black Maternal Health Momnibus Act.
